title: 108_hr2449
content: The Act is titled the "Civil War Sesquicentennial Commission Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purpose section. The American Civil War was a defining experience in the development of the United States, leading to ongoing struggles with issues of race, civil rights, federalism, and heritage. There is a resurgence of interest in the Civil War, especially during the sesquicentennial years of 2011-2015, providing an opportunity for Americans to recall and reflect. The United States Civil War Center at Louisiana State University and the Civil War Institute at Gettysburg College have been designated to plan and facilitate the commemoration of the sesquicentennial of the Civil War. Virginia, with its numerous historic sites and institutions, plays a significant role in preserving the legacy of the Civil War. The African American Civil War Museum in Washington, D.C. is dedicated to studying the role of African Americans in the Civil War. The purpose of the Act is to establish a Civil War Sesquicentennial Commemoration Commission to ensure a national observance of the sesquicentennial of the Civil War and assist states and organizations with related programs and activities. The Civil War Sesquicentennial Commemoration Commission aims to ensure an inclusive observance of the Civil War and support educational programs and activities related to the war. The Secretary of the Interior will establish the Civil War Sesquicentennial Commemoration Commission, referred to as the "Commission", to oversee the observance of the Civil War and support educational programs related to the war. The Commission, composed of 25 members, includes government representatives appointed by various officials such as the Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate. It also includes key figures like the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution. The Commission, consisting of 25 members, includes government representatives appointed by officials like the Chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities and private members appointed by the President. The Commission, consisting of 25 members, includes individuals with expertise in history, art history, historic preservation, anthropology, cultural geography, sociology, political science, law, and economics. Members are appointed for life, vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission, with 25 members from various fields, must be appointed within 60 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 5. GENERAL PROVISIONS. The Commission appointed under section 4 shall hold meetings, elect a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson, require a majority for a quorum, and make decisions based on a majority vote of voting members. The Commission appointed under section 4 shall have nonvoting members who serve in an advisory capacity. The Commission appointed under section 4 shall have nonvoting members who serve in an advisory capacity. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission appointed under section 4 shall have nonvoting members who serve in an advisory capacity. The Commission shall plan, develop, and carry out programs to commemorate the sesquicentennial of the Civil War, encourage interdisciplinary examination, facilitate Civil War-related activities, coordinate scholarly research distribution, and provide technical assistance for commemoration efforts. The Commission appointed under section 4 plans to commemorate the sesquicentennial of the Civil War by developing programs, facilities, and international involvement. They will prepare strategic and annual performance plans, along with submitting reports. The Commission appointed under section 4 will submit an annual report to Congress listing gifts over $250 and their donors, and a final report by December 30, 2015, including a summary of activities, financial accounting, and recommendations. The National Endowment for the Humanities will award grants for activities related to the sesquicentennial of the Civil War, focusing on the role of African Americans. The Commission has powers outlined in section 8. The Commission has the authority to solicit and use gifts, appoint advisory committees, authorize members to take actions, procure supplies, and use the United States mails. The Commission has the authority to solicit gifts, appoint advisory committees, authorize actions, procure supplies, and use the United States mails like other Federal agencies. SEC. 9. PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission and advisory committee members serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Chairperson can appoint necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director, whose employment needs confirmation by the Commission. The Chairperson has the authority to set the compensation for the executive director and other personnel, with a maximum pay rate specified. The Commission can request Federal agencies to detail personnel to assist without interruption of civil service status. They can also accept voluntary services and receive support services from the National Park Service on a reimbursable basis. The Commission can request administrative support services on a reimbursable basis. The Chairperson can procure temporary services at specified rates. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. The Inspector General of the Department of the Interior will conduct an annual audit of the Commission, with results made public. Authorization of appropriations includes $200,000 for fiscal years 2005-2016 for Act implementation, and $3,500,000 for grants to the National Endowment for the Humanities.
